properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow becoming heavy tonight. This Snowfall Warning replaces a Winter Weather Travel Advisory that was previously in effect. Locally heavy snowfall amounts of 15 cm within 12 hour is now expected tonight. Snow has begun and will become heavy tonight. It will continue through Friday before tapering to flurries Friday night. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 50 km/h will develop on Friday resulting in localized areas of blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-05T12:30:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-04T20:31:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4049007492.2021
Area: Beardmore - Jellicoe - Macdiarmid
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extremely cold wind chills between -55 and -60 continue today and tonight. These extremely cold conditions may persist into the early part of the weekend in some communities. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-05T08:01:45-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of freezing rain is expected. Locations: Green Bay - White Bay Time span: overnight tonight into Friday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 20 to 30 cm snow by Friday morning. A weather system will move over southern BC today spreading snow to the region. Segments of the Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt and Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass will receive 20 to 30 cm snow by Friday morning. Another system will approach the region Friday night. Additional snow of up to 15 cm can be expected on Saturday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-05T05:00:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-04T13:01:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1817540456.2021
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Upwards of 20 cm of snow is expected by Friday morning. A Pacific frontal system moving into the region is forecast to bring more snow to southern British Columbia. Snow is expected to intensify tonight for the Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt and Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass sections and taper off to periods of light snow Friday morning. Another significant system will approach the region Friday night with additional amounts of 15 to 20 cm possible for Saturday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-05T11:04:45-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow becoming heavy this evening into tonight. Snow has begun and will increase in intensity this evening into tonight. The snow will ease in intensity Friday morning before ending later in the day. Total snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 cm are likely by the time the snow comes to an end. Travel conditions along Highway 17 between Nipigon and Wawa will likely become hazardous due to accumulating snow and very low visibility. Motorists should consider changing travel plans accordingly. The town of Wawa is expected to receive lesser amounts than areas farther west along the shore of Lake Superior. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this afternoon and evening. Snow at times heavy, is expected to persist into the evening hours before easing to periods of light snow tonight. Poor winter driving conditions are expected this afternoon due to accumulating snow, particularly on Highways 11 and 17. Motorists should consider changing travel plans accordingly. Total snowfall amounts of 7 to 12 cm are expected by the time the snow tapers off overnight, with some areas possibly approaching 15 cm. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight. Snow is expected to arrive in the area this evening. This snow will be heaviest in the first 3 to 5 hours after onset, with snowfall rates of 2-3 cm per hour possible at times. Accumulations of 7 to 15 cm are expected by Friday morning. Poor winter driving conditions are expected tonight due to accumulating snow and very poor visibility at times. Motorists should consider changing travel plans accordingly. The snow is expected to taper off Friday morning. Snow squalls are forecast to develop off Lake Superior by Friday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: A multi-day episode of very cold wind chills is expected. Extremely cold windchill values near minus 40 will develop later this afternoon. Extreme cold conditions will last into next week. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight. Snow is expected to reach the Windsor and Sarnia areas near 7 P.M. EST then spread northeast to reach an Owen Sound to Kitchener to Brantford line around midnight. At any location, the heaviest snowfall is most likely during the first two or three hours after onset, with lighter snowfall expected after that. Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible tonight with the bulk of the precipitation likely coming in the first few hours. Road conditions are expected to rapidly deteriorate once the snow arrives. Untreated roads may suddenly become snow covered and slippery. Motorists should allow for extra time to reach their destination. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-05T10:47:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-04T18:48:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2488704437.2021

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. An increasing gradient between a trough over Hudson Bay and a ridge over the NWT has created blizzard-like conditions this morning in Coral Harbour. These conditions will improve this afternoon before a second, more prolonged blizzard event begins overnight tonight and ends late Friday morning. Northeasterly winds of 50 gusting 70 km/h along with some falling snow are expected to develop overnight. The winds will ease during the day on Friday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-05T07:49:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-04T15:50:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3294035264.2021
Area: Coral Harbour
